Fig. 1 HR-TEM images reveal the obvious evolution of disorder (a) Pristine SnO2, (b) SEmD-TO (120) (Inset: enlarged view of strongly disordered region), (c) PTA-SEmD-TO (Inset: enlarged view of strongly disordered region), and (d) SEM image of PTA-SEmD-TO. Fig. 2 (a, b) High-resolution XPS spectra showing binding energies of Sn 3d and O 1 s for SnO2, SEmD-TO (120), and PTA-SEmD-TO, (c) DTGA analysis of pristine SnO2, SEmD-TO (120), PTA-SEmD-TO, and (d) Room temperature Raman spectra of as-prepared catalysts. Invigorating surface frustrated Lewis pairs on bifunctional quasi-disordered Sn-based catalyst for solar photothermocatalytic conversion of CO2 from air Muhammad Tayyab Conceptualization Data curation Formal analysis Investigation Methodology Validation Visualization Writing – original draft a Jung-Hyeok Park Methodology Visualization a Kyung-Min Kim Supervision Writing – review & editing b Chang-Ha Lee Conceptualization Funding acquisition Project administration Resources Supervision Writing – review & editing a ⁎ a Department of Chemical and Biomolecular Engineering, Yonsei University, Seoul, Republic of Korea Department of Chemical and Biomolecular Engineering Yonsei University Seoul Republic of Korea Department of Chemical and Biomolecular Engineering, Yonsei University, Seoul, Republic of Korea b Department of Biochemical Engineering, Gangneung-Wonju National University, Gangneung-si, Republic of Korea Department of Biochemical Engineering Gangneung-Wonju National University Gangneung-si Republic of Korea Department of Biochemical Engineering, Gangneung-Wonju National University, Gangneung-si, Republic of Korea ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract Designing adsorption-enhanced solid catalysts with excellent bifunctional features is feasible for achieving carbon neutrality. In this study, surface-frustrated Lewis pair sites (sFLPs) were fabricated on a quasi-disordered Sn catalyst. Catalysts with different degrees of disorder were synthesized by thermochemical control. The disordered catalyst exhibited randomly distributed lattice disorder, in-plane oxygen vacancies, and mixed-valence Sn. The coexistence of Sn (IV, II) Lewis acidic sites and −OH Lewis basic sites was crucial in the activation of CO2. In addition, sFLPs were further stimulated on the disorder-engineered surface using simultaneous inclusion of PTA (W6+) and hydroxylation. The optimized catalyst exhibited an exceptionally high adsorption capacity and photothermocatalytic activity for 400 ppm CO2 in air compared to pristine SnO2. The enhanced adsorption and photothermocatalytic activity were attributed to distinctive chemistry of the redox-active sFLPs. This study highlights the potential of high-density sFLPs on disordered catalysts for CO2 abatement from the air. Keywords Frustrated Lewis pairs Disordered catalyst In-plane vacancies CO2 adsorption and activation Photothermocatalytic CO2 reduction Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction The adverse effects on global climate due to the rise in atmospheric CO2 concentrations have made the adoption of intensive strategies to limit CO2 emissions urgent. The development of rationally designed catalysts for low-concentration CO2 conversion to produce chemicals and fuels with low energy requirements can contribute to decreasing atmospheric CO2 levels [1,2]. Numerous studies have explored the feasibility of carbon capture, utilization, and storage (CCUS). The significance of bifunctional solid catalysts for the demand-led capture or chemical reduction of CO2 enables the direct utilization of low concentrations of CO2, offering the potential for decentralized implementation [3]. This approach eliminates the need for separate facilities for CO2 capture, transportation, and storage [4]. Among the various approaches, the conversion of CO2 using H2O via solar-driven catalysis at a gas-solid interface is innovative [5,6]. Solar-driven catalysis faces low conversion challenges due to the ineffective activation of inert CO2 and multiple charge transport processes. One established approach to enhancing the photocatalytic CO2 reduction reaction is to create nominal point defects while keeping the crystal structure intact [7,8]. However, recent studies have shown that quasi-order-disordered catalysts can form metal-hydroxide bonds (order-disorder). The disorder-induced OH (Lewis base) can develop surface-frustrated Lewis pair sites (sFLPs) with adjacent metal sites (Lewis acids). The incorporation of sFLPs onto disordered engineered metal oxides introduces multiple synergistic effects. sFLPs provide highly favorable sites for the activation of small molecules (CO2, H2, and NO). Moreover, sFLPs facilitate the migration of photo-induced electrons to CO2, enhancing the photothermocatalytic activity [9]. Moreover, these can improve vis-IR photon harvesting and the separation of photogenerated charge carriers [10]. Therefore, sFLPs on metal oxide surfaces could significantly enhance photothermocatalytic activity [11]. However, a comprehensive understanding of synthesis approaches, surface science, physicochemical properties, and CO2 photothermocatalytic activity trends is required. Reducible metal oxides possess a greater potential for metal reduction in reaction environments due to the higher density of donor states compared to irreducible metal oxides [12,13]. Sn-based catalysts have traditionally been considered unsuitable for CO2 reduction due to unfavorable theoretical redox potentials, suboptimal active sites, and metal reduction during reactions [14]. Therefore, SO4 2−-embedded quasi-disordered mixed valence (SEmD-TO) catalysts were synthesized in this study and featured a delocalized valence band edge, improved surface chemistry, a larger specific surface area, optimal active sites, and visible region light absorption. Thermochemical control over crystal nucleation and growth enabled the manipulation of the disorder-related −OH (Lewis base) and the coexistence of Sn (IV, II) (Lewis acid). The as-prepared catalyst exhibited a higher propensity to adsorb 400 ppm of CO2 and enhanced photothermocatalytic conversion of CO2 into CO compared to pristine crystalline SnO2. The redox-active sFLPs were further enhanced through the simultaneous uniform dispersion of phosphotungstic acid (PTA) and hydroxylation, resulting in an sFLPs-enriched W6+ − Sn (IV) − O − Sn (II) − OH catalyst (PTA-SEmD-TO). The defective surface enabled strong interactions between the O atoms of PTA and SnO2 to form Sn − O − W bonds. This could create a heterojunction between PTA (W6+) and SnO2. Therefore, highly dispersed PTA at the interface of the disordered surface led to an improved electronic and structural environment for CO2 reduction. In addition, the 400 ppm CO2/air condition demonstrated suitability for CO2 reduction caused by the dynamic interaction of O2 with photogenerated Vo (oxygen vacancies). The chemisorbed O2 repopulated the photogenerated Vo and stabilized the Sn valence state. The as-prepared catalyst (PTA-SEmD-TO) demonstrated superior bifunctional activity toward atmospheric CO2 capture and selective conversion into CO through a photothermocatalytic process. This study provides insight into the design of efficient catalysts for low-concentration gas-phase CO2 elimination from air. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Materials The following chemicals were used without further modification: Tin (IV) chloride pentahydrate (98 %, Sigma-Aldrich), phosphotungstic acid hydrate (reagent grade, Sigma-Aldrich), thiourea (reagent plus ≥99 %, Sigma-Aldrich), ethanol (anhydrous 99.5 %, Daejung Chemicals), deionized water (HPLC grade, Daejung-Korea), ammonium hydroxide solution (ACS reagent, 28.0–30.0 % NH3 basis, Sigma-Aldrich), KBr powder (PIKE Technologies), 13CO2 (13C, 99 %, <2% 18O, Cambridge Isotope Laboratories, Inc.). 2.2 Catalyst synthesis 2.2.1 Preparation of pristine SnO2 Pristine SnO2 was prepared using a modified precipitation method without any surfactants [15]. First, SnCl4·5H2O (10 mmol) was dissolved in 100 mL of DI water over 30 min. Then, an ammonium hydroxide solution was added dropwise to the Sn precursor solution. The pH of the solution was adjusted to 10.5, followed by stirring for 1 h. The precipitate was separated by centrifugation and washed several times with DI water. The wet sample was dried in an oven at 100 °C for 8 h. Finally, the dried sample was ground and calcined at 600 °C under static air for 2 h. 2.2.2 Preparation of sulfur-embedded quasi-disordered SnO2 SnO2 with disordered and sFLPs was synthesized using two solvents under reflux at 90 °C in an oil bath [16]. Thiourea (1.52 g) was dissolved in 100 mL of ethanol at room temperature for 20 min. Meanwhile, SnCl4·5H2O (3.5 g) was dissolved in 75 mL of DI water at 90 °C in a three-necked flask equipped with a reflux condenser. The dissolved thiourea solution was slowly added to the Sn precursor solution, resulting in a milky suspension within 10 min. The mixture was then stirred for 3 h under reflux. The suspension was cooled naturally, and the precipitates were separated by centrifugation and washed with ethanol and DI water. The obtained wet samples were dried in ambient air prior to thermal treatment. The synthesis procedure for all disordered SnO2 catalysts was the same, except for the final step of thermal treatment at different temperatures to engineer disorder and optimize catalyst features and activities. The S-embedded disordered SnO2 catalyst (SEmD-TO (AS)) was obtained by further drying the air-dried precursor in an oven at 60 °C for 8 h. SEmD-TO (120) was obtained after heating the precursor at 120 °C for 12 h in a vacuum oven, and SEmD-TO (350) was synthesized by calcining in an argon environment by ramping the temperature to 350 °C at a ramp rate of 3 °C and dwelling for 2 h in a horizontal tube furnace. The parentheses values in each catalyst name indicate the treatment temperature. 2.2.3 Preparation of phosphotungstic acid incorporated disordered SnO2 Phosphotungstic acid (PTA) was uniformly dispersed on SEmD-TO (120) to further improve its catalytic activity toward CO2 via sFLPs enrichment. As-prepared SEmD-TO (120) (0.2 g) was dispersed in 10 mL of DI water in a round-bottomed flask. PTA (0.01 mmol) was dissolved in 10 mL of DI water. The PTA solution was then added dropwise to the SEmD-TO (120) solution, and the resulting mixture was transferred to an oil bath and kept under reflux at 80 °C for 24 h. After cooling the suspension, a precipitate was obtained by centrifugation. Finally, the precursor was heated in an oven to obtain the final, whitish-colored PTA-SEmD-TO catalyst. 2.3 Characterizations The morphologies and elemental mapping of the as-prepared catalysts were studied using field-emission scanning electron microscopy (FE-SEM, JEOL-7800F) and energy-dispersive spectroscopy (EDS). The lattice and structural features were analyzed using a cs-corrected transmission electron microscope (JEM-ARM200F (NEOARM)). Crystalline properties were examined via powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) within a 2θ range of 10–100° using an Ultima IV (Rigaku, Japan) with Cu Kα as the beam source (wavelength of 1.54 Å). The specific surface areas of the as-synthesized catalysts were obtained from N2 isotherms at 77 K (Autosorb iQ, Quantachrome) using the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method. The catalysts were pretreated under vacuum at 120 °C for 8 h prior to N2 isotherm measurements. Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR; Bruker Vertex 70) was used to examine the surface functional groups using the KBr pelleting method. For the pyridine FTIR analysis, 0.1 g of the as-synthesized catalysts were pretreated at 120 °C for 3 h in a vacuum oven. Then, 100 μL of pyridine was added to the catalysts and kept for 30 min to achieve adsorption. Next, the weakly adsorbed pyridine evaporated at 100 °C for 90 min. Finally, an appropriate amount of the catalyst was diluted with KBr, pressed into pellets, and measured. Elemental analysis and the oxidation states of the elements were analyzed using an X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, Thermo Fisher Scientific) equipped with a monochromatic Al Kα X-ray source. XPS measurements to study H2 activation were conducted after exposing PTA-SEmD-TO to an H2 environment at room temperature. All binding-energy data were corrected with respect to adventitious carbon at 284.8 eV. Thermogravimetric weight loss analysis was performed on a Perkin Elmer (TG-4000) instrument from 30 to 800 °C under air flow. The UV–Vis diffuse reflectance absorption spectra were collected using a DR-UV/Vis SCINCO S-4100 spectrophotometer with an integral sphere. The Raman spectra were obtained at room temperature using a LabRam Aramis Raman system equipped with a multichannel 1024×256 air-cooled CCD detector. The irradiation beam source was an ND: YAG laser with a wavelength of 532 nm. Photoluminescence (PL) spectra were recorded at room temperature using a 325 nm He-Cd laser as the excitation source (LabRam Aramis). Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS, Chenhua Instrument, CHI 660) was performed using a three-electrode system to obtain the Nyquist plots. Ag/AgCl, Pt foil, and 0.1 M Na2SO4 were used as the reference, counter electrodes, and electrolyte, respectively. The as-prepared catalyst (1 mg) was suspended in 1 mL of methanol with 10 μL of Nafion to yield a homogeneous suspension. The prepared suspension was dropped onto a glassy carbon surface and dried to obtain the working electrode. Low-temperature solid-state electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) spectra were recorded on a Bruker EMX plus spectrometer equipped with a dual-mode DM1012 resonator at 9.64 GHz, 0.93 mW power, and 100 KHz modulation frequency. A low temperature (4 K) was achieved using a continuous-flow ESR cryostat (ESR900, Oxford Instruments) equipped with an intelligent temperature controller (ITC503, Oxford Instruments). 2.4 Adsorption activity measurement 2.4.1 Ultra dilute CO2 uptake test Gravimetric CO2 uptake experiments were conducted using a Perkin Elmer TGA (TG-4000) instrument with embedded mass flow controllers (MFCs). First, the as-prepared catalysts were placed in an alumina crucible and pretreated at 120 °C for 2 h under a nitrogen flow of 40 mL/min. Then, the sample was cooled to 30 °C (±1 °C) and kept in nitrogen flow for an additional 30 min to get N2 adsorption saturation and temperature stabilization before the uptake measurement. The gas was then switched to 400 ppm CO2 balanced with He, 100 % CO2, or 400 ppm CO2 balanced with air at a rate of 30 mL/min for 2 h. Finally, the resulting weight changes were converted to a standard scale of milligrams of CO2 adsorbed per milligram of catalyst. 2.4.2 CO2 adsorption isotherm measurement The adsorption isotherms of CO2 up to 1 bar were measured at 25 °C using a volumetric method with a gas sorption analyzer (Quantachrome Instruments, Autosorb IQ). Prior to measurements, the catalysts (∼100 mg) were degassed under vacuum at 120 °C for 8 h. 2.5 In situ DRIFTS experiments 2.5.1 CO2 interaction and activation mechanism study To study the interaction mechanism of CO2 with pristine SnO2 and SEmD-TO (120), in situ diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier-transform spectroscopy (DRIFTS; Nicolet iS10, Thermo Scientific) was employed. The samples were prepared by diluting the catalyst with KBr at a mass ratio of 1:9. Prior to the measurement, the samples were pretreated in an He environment at a flow rate of 30 mL/min at 120 °C for 1 h in a DRIFTS cell equipped with a Zn-Se window and temperature controller. After pretreatment, the sample was cooled to 30 °C, and the temperature was maintained at 30 °C for CO2 interaction studies. Next, wet 400 ppm of CO2 in air (mixed gas) was supplied to the cell at 30 mL/min using an MFC. A bubbler was installed to supply H2O to the feed gas, and the water content was measured using a humidity detector (∼70 % RH). The spectral data were collected at 4000–1000 cm−1 using a mercury cadmium telluride (MCT) cryodetector. 2.5.2 Room temperature H2 activation study for sFLPs detection In situ DRIFTS studies were conducted using the sample preparation method described above to explore the room-temperature heterolytic H2 activation on pristine SnO2 and PTA-SEmD-TO. The samples were pretreated under a He flow at 120 °C for 1 h. Next, the catalysts were cooled to 30 °C, and the measurement was carried out by supplying H2 feed gas for 30 min, and data were collected using an MCT detector. 2.6 Gas phase CO2 photothermocatalytic experiments Photothermocatalytic CO2 reduction experiments were conducted in a 200-mL custom-built sealed batch-type steel reactor equipped with a heater and a quartz top. The as-prepared catalysts (20 mg) were mixed with a few droplets of DI water and evenly coated onto glass plates (2 cm × 2 cm). Subsequently, the glass plate was oven-dried at 100 °C and placed on a platform inside a reactor. After sealing the reaction vessel, the feed gas (400 ppm CO2/air, 400 ppm CO2/He, or 100 % CO2) was passed through a water bubbler to prepare a CO2-water gas mixture of ∼70 % RH. The prefix “wet” is not mentioned hereafter for simplicity. The gas mixture was supplied to the reactor via an inlet line equipped with a valve at a flow rate of 30 mL/min for 30 min to reach equilibrium. A thermocouple was installed inside the reactor below the catalyst platform to monitor the temperature. The reactor temperature was controlled using a temperature controller and adjusted to the desired temperatures (30–150 °C) within 20 min. After the reactor reached the targeted temperature, the inside pressure was measured to be 1.1±0.02 bar before initiating light irradiation. The total pressure inside the reactor remained constant during the experiments owing to the constant stoichiometric ratios of the reactants and products. Photothermocatalytic activity was evaluated for the as-prepared catalysts under a solar light simulator (Peccell, PEC-L01) equipped with an AM 1.5 G filter. The solar simulator was operated at 6.9 A to generate an irradiation intensity of 100 mW/cm2 (∼1 sun) at the catalyst’s surface. The insignificant rise in reactor temperature (4–5 °C) was observed due to the low irradiation intensity (100 mW/cm2). A gas mixture (300 μL) was collected from the reactor and analyzed using a gas chromatograph (GC; Agilent 8890) equipped with a methanizer. The reaction mixture was separated using a temperature-programmed oven and 60/80 carboxene-1000 column. A standard calibration curve was used to determine the amount of CO produced. To evaluate the photothermocatalytic efficiency of the conversion of CO2 to CO, R C O 2 activity expressed in terms of the CO concentration (ppm) normalized per gram of catalysts over one hour was determined using Eq. P a . mol - 2 , and b = 39.3 × 10 - 6 m 3 . mol - 1 are constants. Isotope labeling experiments were conducted by substituting 12CO2 with 13CO2. The reactor and lines were thoroughly purged with ultrahigh-purity (UHP) helium for 1 h to eliminate any undesired gases from the system. The reactor was then filled with wet 13CO2 (99 %, <1 % 18O; Cambridge Isotope Laboratories, Inc.) and purged for 20 min. The reaction products were analyzed by GC-FID (Agilent 8890) and GC-mass spectrometry (Agilent 8890-5977B MSD). 3 Results and discussions 3.1 Disorder-related atomic structure and morphologies The crystallographic features of the as-prepared catalysts were analyzed using spherical-aberration-corrected HR-TEM. Pristine SnO2 (Fig. 1 a) displayed a crystalline structure with a long-range ordered lattice arrangement without apparent distortions. However, SEmD-TO (120) and PTA-SEmD-TO exhibited randomly arranged quasi-order-disorder periodicities with unclear grain boundaries and terminated lattice fringes, as shown in the HR-TEM images in Fig. 1b and c. The enlarged view of circled regions SEmD-TO (120) (Fig. 1b: inset) and PTA-SEmD-TO (Fig. 1c: inset) showed the absence of short-range atomic ordering due to disorder in the catalyst structures. A hetero-transition zone was also formed between the ordered and disordered regions. Quasi-periodicity can enhance catalytic activity by providing active sites and creating unique electronic configurations [9]. Atomic bright-field scanning tunneling electron microscopy (ABF-STEM) (Fig. S1) and high-angle annular dark-field (HAADF-STEM) (Fig. S2) were used to resolve the atomic arrangements of the as-prepared crystalline catalysts (pristine SnO2) and SEmD-TO (120). The results showed a well-arranged lattice configuration for SnO2. However, distorted lattices and amorphous regions were observed in SEmD-TO (120). Furthermore, in Fig. S1b (indicated by arrows), a clearly defined and sharp boundary was observed between the two planes, suggesting a well-defined crystal facet orientation for pristine SnO2 compared to other disorder-induced catalysts. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) was used to examine the morphological features of the prepared catalysts. Pristine SnO2 (Fig. S3a) exhibited an irregular polygonal morphology with sharp edges owing to its higher crystallinity. PTA-SEmD-TO (Fig. 1d) and other disordered catalysts (Fig. S3b – d) displayed similar irregular polygons but rough surfaces and indistinct edges. This feature was derived from the well-dispersed solvated SO4 2− anions in the water-solvent attached to the growing SnO2 surfaces, which limited nucleation kinetics and induced structural disorder [16]. In addition, the elemental mapping of SEmD-TO (120) and PTA-SEmD-TO (Fig. S4) confirmed the presence of S, along with Sn and O. Furthermore, W element (Fig. S4j) was found to be well-dispersed on the PTA-SEmD-TO surface without clustering. The dispersion of W on the PTA-SEmD-TO surface confirmed the interaction between W6+ (PTA) and SnO2. The dispersed PTA (W6+) on the disordered metal oxide (SnO2) forms an interfacial heterojunction and provides additional acidic sites. 3.2 Chemical compositions, disorder-related features, and oxygen vacancy position XPS was used to determine the oxygen configurations and metal valence states of the as-prepared catalysts. The XPS survey spectra (Fig. S5) indicated the presence of specific elements in each catalyst. For example, in pristine SnO2, Sn and O were detected, while Sn, O, and S were detected in the S-embedded catalysts. In addition, PTA-SEmD-TO contained W, along with Sn, O, and S. The Sn 3d spectra shown in Fig. 2 a and Fig. S6a were deconvoluted into two sub-peaks corresponding to the mixed Sn (IV) and Sn (II) valence states of Sn for all disordered catalysts. In contrast, pristine SnO2 exhibited only the Sn (IV) valence state. During the synthesis of disordered catalysts, the interaction of SO4 2− with the growing Sn impeded crystal growth and formed coordination complexes with the Sn ions. The presence of sulfate species during the synthesis of the catalysts resulted in structural disorder and created ample Vo. Subsequently, the structural disorder induced Vo prompted a partial reduction of Sn (IV) to Sn (II) [18]. Sn (IV, II) formed two metastable states, facilitating oxygen adsorption and promoting vacancy formation [19]. The active oxygen adsorption at the metastable sites was favorable for promoting redox reaction activities. Moreover, the disordered catalysts presented a relative shift in binding energies (±0.9 eV), which originated from changes in the local electronic environment near the Sn centers owing to variations in the extent of disorder and concentration of Vo after different thermal treatments (Table S2). The high-resolution O 1 s spectra (Fig. 2b and Fig. S6b) were resolved into three peaks, corresponding to lattice oxygen in Sn − O − Sn (530.5±0.4 eV), oxygen species close to Vo sites (531.7±0.7 eV), and Sn − OH, or surface adsorbed H2O (532.5±0.3 eV) [20,21]. A high content of −OH (Table S2) in disordered catalysts corresponded to the involvement of reacted −OH species bonded with Sn during synthesis to create Sn − OH-related disorder. Therefore, the origin of the disorder and hydroxylation is ascribed to the provision of −OH groups that reacted with the growing Sn (IV, II) cations to form Sn (IV) − O − Sn (II) − (OH) [9,14]. Furthermore, as the synthesis temperature increased (Table S2), the concentration of the Vo subpeak increased and the lattice oxygen decreased. The thermochemical modifications (SO4 2−-associated) caused the emergence of various concentrations of in-plane Vo, contributing to different degrees of disorder. The reduction in lattice oxygen (Sn-OL) and increase in Sn − OH (Table S2) suggest the collapse of the crystal structure and an increase in the degree of disorder. The small peaks at 163.1 eV in high-resolution S 2p spectra of SEmD-TO catalysts (Fig. S6c) indicated the presence of sulfur component. This peak was consistent with partially oxidized sulfur bonded with the oxygen atoms of SnO2 [22]. Furthermore, the −OH concentration increased from 31 % in SEmD-TO (120) to 35 % in PTA-SEmD-TO (Table S2). This increase was denoted as hydroxylation during the PTA (W6+) dispersion on SEmD-TO (120) in an aqueous medium. Consistently, the TGA and DTGA analyses (Fig. S7 and Fig. 2c) showed a larger weight loss of water (8 % at <200 °C) for PTA-SEmD-TO than for SEmD-TO (120) and pristine SnO2. Therefore, W6+− Sn (IV) − O − Sn (II) − (OH) is expected to exhibit properties distinct from those of pristine SnO2, such as enhanced proton transfer, CO2 adsorption, and surface reactivity. In addition, high-resolution W 4f (Fig. S8) for PTA-SEmD-TO revealed peaks ascribed to W 4f7/2 and W 4f5/2, which correspond to the W6+ oxidation state. The Raman spectra shown in Fig. 2d further confirmed the structural and disorder-related features of the as-synthesized catalysts. The Raman shift observed from 305 to 355 cm−1 in all disordered catalysts corresponds to the Eu (TO) modes, which became IR active due to imperfections in the crystal structure or size reduction [23]. The pristine SnO2 displayed typical Raman-active vibrations at 474 cm−1, 632 cm−1, and 773 cm−1 corresponding to the classic doubly degenerated Eg, A1g, and B2g Raman active modes [24]. Notably, the as-prepared disordered catalysts showed broadened and less intense Raman modes (400–700 cm−1) because of the lack of a well-defined structural arrangement, causing a reduced coherence of the vibrational modes and lower Raman scattering efficiency corroborating with XRD results (Fig. 3 a). Gaussian deconvolution for SnO2 (375–575 cm−1) and SEmD-TO (120) (400–700 cm−1) was performed to resolve these peaks (Fig. S9). The vibrational bands exhibited in Fig. 2d at 249 (Eu (TO)) and the deconvoluted bands displayed in Fig. S9 at 501 (Eg) and 540 cm−1 (B1u(3)) for pristine SnO2 correspond to out-of-plane sub-bridging and bridging oxygen vacancies [20,25]. Conversely, SEmD-TO (120) showed a unique vibrational mode at 569 cm−1 (D-band), ascribed to the in-plane Vo caused by the formation of Sn (IV) − O − Sn (II) − (OH) [26]. Furthermore, thermally induced chemical modifications occurred as the synthesis temperature increased under oxygen-deprived conditions. As a result, the corresponding peaks became broader and less intense, owing to a further reduction in the local symmetry and elimination of oxygen atoms from the lattice. Specifically, Fig. S10 (enlarged view) showed that SEmD-TO (350) displays a Raman shift (600 cm−1) as a result of an increase in disorder and Vo [26]. The Raman shifts at 943 and 870 cm−1 for PTA-SEmD-TO (Fig. 2d) represent the characteristic vibrational modes of W − O in the primary kegging structure. The absence of WO3 and W = Ot (981–997 cm−1) related vibrations in the Raman spectra suggested the stable interaction of PTA and formation of Sn − O − W bonds, which weakens the W = Ot (terminal oxygen in the Keggin structure) bonds to form strong metal-O-W interaction, similarly reported by previous studies [27,28,29]. 3.3 Phase structures, textural properties, and sFLPs-related surface analysis The powder XRD pattern of pristine SnO2 (Fig. 3a) reveals a well-defined crystalline structure assigned to the tetragonal phase of rutile SnO2 [JCPDS:41–1445]. However, the S-embedded catalysts (SEmD-TO) expressed broader and less intense peaks, indicating decreased crystallinity and a smaller crystal size [30]. Interestingly, the intensity of the XRD peaks for disordered catalysts negligibly increased with an increase in the treatment temperature compared to the significant weakening and broadening of the Raman peaks (Fig. 2d). It suggested that the crystal size changes were trivial. The thermal treatment in a vacuum environment promoted the significant creation of surface and bulk Vo during the synthesis. Moreover, the PTA-SEmD-TO pattern was identical to SEmD-TO (120), except for a slight improvement in crystallinity because of Sn − Ot − W. The N2 adsorption–desorption isotherms of the as-prepared catalysts are presented in Fig. S11. Table S3 lists the BET surface area (SBET), pore volume (VT), and average pore diameter (Pdia). Notably, as shown in Fig. 3b, the S-embedded catalysts demonstrated higher SBET (143–189 m2/g) than pristine SnO2 (30 m2/g). The pore size distribution estimated by the BJH method (Figs. S12a and b) for the disordered catalysts indicated a narrow pore size distribution and a smaller mean pore diameter (ranging between 2 and 2.66 nm). FTIR spectroscopy (Fig. 3c) was used to confirm the presence of sFLPs and surface functional groups. Pristine SnO2 exhibited doublet peaks at 475 and 630 cm−1, representing the O − Sn − O and Sn − O vibrations, respectively. In contrast, the disordered catalysts displayed a sharp peak at 552 cm−1 due to the strain imposed on the Sn − O bond by an attached OH group (Sn − OH) [31]. The vibrational bands at 3430 and 1620 cm−1 were ascribed to stretching and bending −OH vibrations, respectively. Pristine SnO2 exhibited weak stretching and bending −OH vibrational modes associated with a dehydroxylated surface and the absence of sFLPs. In addition, H2O binding at the defect sites (stretching −OH) established conventional BrØnsted acid sites. In contrast, PTA-SEmD-TO showed pronounced −OH peaks at 3237 (bridging −OH), 3430 (stretching −OH), and 3615 cm−1 (terminal −OH). The results clearly suggested that H2O dissociated at the Lewis acidic Sn (IV, II) sites and released protons coordinated with the neighboring Lewis basic lattice oxygen [9,32]. This indicated that H2O was dissociated at the sFLPs sites instead of binding at the Vo to form BrØnsted acid sites. Moreover, the characteristic absorption bands for the PTA were observed in FTIR spectra of PTA-SEmD-TO at 800–1100 cm−1, which denoted the kegging structure of PTA, confirming the interaction of SnO2 surface with the WO6 units of PTA. In Fig. 3c, the vibrational peak at 1401 cm−1 was attributed to surface-attached covalently bonded sulfate groups (S = O), while the peak at 1251 cm−1 was assigned to the asymmetric stretching vibration of O = S = O. These peaks confirmed that the sulfur specimen was present as triply bridging sulfate and bridged bidentate sulfate [22]. Combined with XPS S 2p (Fig. S6c), FTIR results revealed a close connection of S with Sn − O, confirming the assumption of sulfur-induced disorder [33]. The sulfate ions were expected to intensify the Lewis acid sites through covalent interactions with Sn (IV, II). The presence of acidic sites was corroborated by chemisorbed pyridine FTIR analysis (Fig. S13). Specifically, SEmD-TO (120) had both Lewis acid and BrØnsted acid sites, whereas SnO2 displayed negligible vibrational bands associated with acid sites. The interaction between PTA (W6+) and Sn (IV) − O − Sn (II) − OH (PTA-SEmD (TO)) also resulted in higher concentrations of Lewis acid sites (1452 and 1614 cm−1). The presence of significantly pronounced −OH species and Lewis acid sites in PTA-SEmD-TO indicates the enhanced strength of the sFLPs [34,35]. A schematic of the as-prepared catalyst is shown in Fig. 3d. Pristine SnO2 has an arranged atomic configuration with an intrinsic out-of-plane Vo. In contrast, the quasi-disordered catalysts consist of mixed-valence Sn (IV, II) metal states, amorphous regions, and in-plane Vo. The presence of Sn-OH suggested the appearance of disorder in the structure. Various analyses confirmed the disorder-induced structural distortions, defects, and reduced crystallinity (Fig. 2 and Fig. 3a). The same mechanism was reported in which OH was incorporated with Ti (IV, III) to induce disorder [9]. Furthermore, the unique spatial arrangement of Lewis basic −OH sites and Lewis acidic Sn (IV, II) sites on the disordered catalysts produced sFLPs. Specifically, intense sFLPs on PTA-SEmD-TO are expected to promote catalytic features. The abundant formation of sFLPs on the PTA-SEmD-TO surface was further verified through in-situ DRIFTS and XPS analyses for H2 activation as a fundamental characteristic of sFLPs. The in-situ DRIFT spectra for PTA-SEmD-TO were recorded to elucidate the sFLPs features in a H2 atmosphere at 30 °C (Fig. 4 a). The vibrational peak at 1626 cm−1 was assigned to the terminal Sn − H− species, with the possibility of overlapping contributions from the stretching modes of Sn − H+ and Sn − OH2 + generated by proton migration [36].The peak at 1398 cm−1 was ascribed to Sn − H− on Sn (IV, II) sites with different Lewis acidities. Furthermore, the peak at 1457 cm−1 in the 3rd scan was of the bridging Sn − H − Sn associated with terminal Sn − H−, Sn − OH+, and Sn − OH2 +. Similarly, the peaks at 1000–1300 cm−1 might be assigned to Sn − H− or Sn − OH2 + on the sFLPs sites with various Lewis acidities and basicity [37]. The peaks at 3000–3600 cm−1 (Fig. 4b) could be associated with Sn − OH+ and Sn − OH2 + species. Specifically, the peak at 3605 cm−1 can be assigned to the bridging Sn − OH+−Sn, whereas the peak at 3428 cm−1 suggested the presence of protonated Sn − OH2 + and Sn − OH with different Lewis basicity [5,38]. Moreover, the peak at 3085 cm−1 suggested hydroxyl formation at different surface positions. Proximal Lewis acid-base properties of metal and OH/O2 – sites facilitate heterolytic splitting of H2. Similarly, when H2 interacted with Lewis acidic Sn (IV, II) sites, it formed Sn-H− species. Simultaneously, Lewis basic OH sites developed Sn-OH2 + species. The appearance of bands associated with Sn-H− and Sn-OH2 + species indicated that H2 undergoes heterolytic splitting on Lewis acidic and basic sites present at appropriate proximity [39,40]. In contrast, no significant changes were observed in the DRIFT spectra of the pristine SnO2 (Fig. S14), indicating an absence of sFLPs. The corresponding high-resolution XPS profiles of PTA-SEmD-TO exposed to H2 at room temperature were also recorded. In Fig. 4c, a slight positive shift (+0.1 eV) was observed in the O 1 s spectrum, suggesting the formation of hydroxyl species after the addition of H+. Conversely, the W 4f spectra (Fig. 4d) exhibited a negative shift (-0.24 eV), accompanied by a slight shift in the Sn 3d spectra (Fig. S15). These shifts suggested the potential splitting of H2 by the sFLPs through protonation, which supports the existence of sFLPs [5,37]. Additionally, no physical changes were observed in the catalyst after H2 exposure at room temperature. 3.4 CO2 adsorption, activation, and O2-related surface chemistry As depicted in Fig. 5 a, the low-concentration CO2 (400 ppm CO2/He) adsorption activity of the as-prepared catalysts was investigated by measuring CO2 uptakes using TGA at 30 °C. Pristine SnO2, which had the lowest surface area, unfavorable surface chemistry, and smaller pore volume, demonstrated negligible CO2 uptake. The slight downshift observed in the SnO2 uptake curve originated from the buoyancy effect and indicated no quantifiable CO2 uptake in the TGA measurements. However, all other disordered catalysts exhibited appreciably superior CO2 uptakes (∼0.0021 mg CO2/mgcat) with slight variations. A comparison of the CO2 uptake between 400 ppm CO2 and 100 % CO2 was also performed (Fig. 5b). The TGA adsorption uptake kinetics demonstrated a significantly faster CO2 uptake for SEmD-TO (120) at 100 % concentration than at 400 ppm CO2, likely because of the high concentration difference. However, the CO2 uptake capacity of pristine SnO2 was negligible, regardless of the CO2 concentration. Furthermore, the CO2 adsorption isotherm of SEmD-TO (120) (Fig. 5c) obtained at 25 °C showed substantial CO2 adsorption in the low-pressure region. These results highlight the significance of the improvement in the surface chemistry and the presence of sFLPs for the adsorption of CO2 at low concentrations (atmospheric CO2). Additionally, the CO2 adsorption isotherm at 25 °C (Fig. 5d) up to 1 bar revealed that SEmD-TO (120) possessed a significant adsorption capacity, whereas pristine SnO2 exhibited a negligible adsorption capacity. In direct air capture and utilization (DACU), a significant oxygen fraction (21 %) in the atmosphere may significantly influence CO2 adsorption, activation, and subsequent conversion activity. In the case of a disordered catalyst with sFLPs, the necessity of oxygen separation can be eliminated because oxygen species may also participate in stabilizing the Sn valence state. The adsorption capacities of 400 ppm CO2/He and 400 ppm CO2/air (Fig. S16) were compared for SEmD-TO (120). The CO2 uptake capacity increased in the presence of an O2 environment, which is the same as that reported in the literature [41,42]. This increase signified the potential activation of O2 as O2 – at the in-plane Vo sites. These negatively charged O2 – (Lewis basic sites) acted as intermediary sFLPs (Sn (IV, II) − O2 –) capable of interacting with the positively charged carbon atom of CO2. Consequently, the presence of surface-covered O2 – species may have contributed to the adsorption and activation of CO2 into CO3 2– and HCO3 – species. Although many adsorbents have high uptake capacities, the inefficient activation of captured CO2 often results in a minimal conversion rate and low CO2 utilization efficiency, [43]. Therefore, sFLPs acting as chemisorption sites on disordered catalysts could be essential for efficient CO2 activation and conversion. Thus, an in-situ DRIFTS study (wet 400 ppm CO2 in air) was conducted to elucidate the nonreductive CO2 activation mechanism as a first step toward CO2 conversion. The DRIFT spectra in Fig. 5e showed that CO2 interaction with SEmD-TO (120) rapidly formed monodentate carbonates (m-CO3 2−; 1311, 1475 cm−1), bidentate carbonates (b-CO3 2; 1343, 1580 cm−1), bi-carbonate (HCO3 –; 1410 cm−1), carboxylate (CO2–; 1703 cm−1), and formate (HCOO–, 1762 cm−1) [44,45]. Furthermore, the formation of b-CO3 2− and HCO3 – suggested that CO2 had early coordination preference at Sn (IV, II) − OH and Sn − O2 – sites (intermediary sFLPs) (Equation (4) [46]. The CO2 – formation suggested the spontaneous migration of excess electrons trapped at the Sn (II) centers to the adsorbed CO2 (Equation (5). The DRIFTS spectra at 2600–4000 cm−1 (Fig. 5f) were also examined to analyze water interactions. Consistent with the FTIR discussed before, water coordination showed vibrational peaks at 3201 cm−1 (bridging −OH), 3412 cm−1 (stretching −OH), 3641 cm−1 (terminal −OH), and 3705–3752 cm−1 (Sn (II) − OH) [45,47]. Notably, as time increased, the Sn (II) − OH peak displayed a blue shift (3705 to 3752 cm−1), and its intensity also decreased compared to the stretching −OH vibration. The shift of the Sn (II) − OH peak toward a higher wavenumber indicated an intermolecular interaction between Sn (II) and CO2-H2O-O2, which resulted from changes in the surface electron density and electron migration to CO2 (Equation (5) [48]. Furthermore, the shift and decrease in the bi-carbonate vibrational peak (HCO3 –, 1410 cm−1) could be the transformation of HCO3 – to surface carbonates. Analogously, the monodentate carbonate (1475 cm−1) and water (1645 cm−1) peaks gradually increased over time, according to the reactions in Eqs. (6) and (7) [47]. (4) S n I V , I I - O H - O 2 - + CO 2 + H 2 O → H C O 3 - + CO 3 2 - (5) S n I I + CO 2 → S n ( I V ) - CO 2 - + 2 e - (6) HC O 3 - → H + + CO 3 2 - (7) H + + OH - → H 2 O The surface interaction of O2 was confirmed by the peaks at 1000–1200 cm−1. These peaks correspond to the characteristic vibrations of O2 – stabilized at the Sn (II) and Sn (IV) sites. Moreover, these forms of adsorbed O2 could be observed only at low temperatures and stable until 200 °C. DRIFTS spectra of pristine SnO2 (Fig. S17) displayed broadened vibrational modes at 1423 and 1631 cm−1, corresponding to water species (interfacial water), and at 3419 cm−1 (stretching −OH), suggesting the inertness of pristine SnO2 toward CO2 [49]. In addition, the O2 related vibrational peaks showed slight shifts in position compared to those of SEmD-TO (120). Specifically, the peak at 1094 cm−1 was identified as electrostatically interacting O2 at the paramagnetic Sn3+ centers [50]. Furthermore, the results discussed above were confirmed by replacing 400 ppm CO2 with 100 % CO2 for SEmD-TO (120). The obtained spectra (Fig. S18) revealed identical vibrational modes of chemisorbed CO2 and H2O compared to the 400 ppm CO2/air spectra (Fig. 5e and f), with more pronounced intensities and no O2– vibrational peaks. The structural disorder and nature of atmospheric oxygen adsorption on the catalysts were further explored using solid-state EPR. The catalysts were exposed only to ambient air before examination. The EPR signals (Fig. 6a) observed at a g-value of 4.3 were attributed to Sn3+ associated Vo originating from the Sn3+ unpaired electrons, similar signal was reported in previous study [51]. This signal resulted from the transiently oxidized Sn3+ coordinated in a distorted octahedral. Pristine SnO2 exhibited a minor signal owing to trivial Vo and the absence of Sn (II) (Fig. 2). Conversely, SEmD-TO (120) showed a significantly stronger signal because of the high degree of non-stoichiometry compared to SnO2. Furthermore, PTA-SEmD-TO displayed a slightly weaker signal due to Sn − Ot − W interaction. This metal–metal interaction might prevent further Vo formation. The pristine SnO2 and disordered catalysts displayed different oxygen adsorption behaviors (Fig. 6 b). Notably, pristine SnO2 revealed the localization of electrons at some defects within the lattice (g1: 2.03, g2: 2.02, ge: 2.005, and g3: 1.98) [52],. This result suggests that the electrons and holes in pristine SnO2 could not transfer to the surrounding gas molecules because of the potential barrier at the gas-film interface. Consequently, O2 could only interact electrostatically with the surface. Furthermore, the signal at a g-value of 1.98 indicated the presence of Sn3+. In contrast, SEmD-TO (120) and PTA-SEmD-TO exhibited a broad signal at g ∼ 2.09, corresponding to superoxide anions (O2–) confined at in-plane Vo locations [53]. These O2 – species could be strongly attached to Sn (IV) or Sn (II) and diffuse inside the lattice via the in-plane Vo. These results confirmed that the sFLPs and disordered surfaces were responsible for the activation of CO2 and O2 at Vo and surface sites. 3.5 Electronic properties, light absorption, and charge carrier separation The DR UV–Vis absorption spectra of the as-prepared catalysts are shown in Fig. S19a. Notably, SnO2 exhibited visible light absorption owing to its intrinsic out-of-plane Vo. Furthermore, the disordered catalysts exhibited strong absorption in the Vis-IR region (400–1000 nm), which is associated with the coexistence of Sn (II) and Vo. The corresponding bandgaps were calculated using the KM relationship (Fig. S19b) and are listed in Table S4. As the Vo concentration increased, the catalyst exhibited expanded absorption in the Vis-IR range and smaller bandgap energies. This was also consistent with the observed color change of the catalysts from light to dark (Fig. S19c). In addition, the valence band (VB) edges were estimated from the XPS VB spectra (Evb), as shown in Fig. S20, and the corresponding conduction band edges were calculated using the formula E Cb = E Vb - E Eg (Table S4). The disordered catalysts with mixed Sn (IV, II) displayed dispersion of the VB leading edge and increased intensities pertaining to the delocalization of the VB. The Sn 5s orbital of Sn (II) hybridized with O 2p (Sn 5s-O 2p) because closeness of energy levels [54]. Moreover, the VB spectra of PTA-SEmD-TO (Fig. S21) were deconvoluted into O 2p, Sn 5p-O 2p, and Sn 5s-O 2p components, confirming the delocalization of the valence band edge induced by hybridization. The binding energy separation between the Sn 4d core level and the O 2p edge was measured to determine the exact position of the valence band edge (Fig. S22). The binding energy separation was 23.66 eV, which is consistent with the value reported in an earlier study [55]. The room-temperature photoluminescence (PL) experiments showed a lower PL intensity (Fig. S23) for the disordered catalysts. The minimum PL spectral intensity of PTA-SEmD-TO suggested improved exciton dissociation efficiency [56]. Compared to SEmD-TO (120), the lower PL intensity of PTA-SEmD-TO suggested the enhanced charge transfer from SnO2 surface to PTA due to improved exciton dissociation efficiency. The result indicated that the recombination of photogenerated charges was inhibited due to the establishment of an efficient charge transfer pathway through electronic interaction between PTA and SnO2. EIS measurements were conducted to investigate the charge transfer impedance of the as-synthesized catalysts, and the corresponding Nyquist plots are shown in Fig. S24. PTA-SEmD-TO displayed a small arc in both the high- and low-frequency regions, suggesting a lower charge transfer impedance and lower possibility of charge recombination (Fig. S23). Similarly, SEmD-TO (120) also displayed a smaller arc than the pristine SnO2 (crystalline) catalyst. An energy-band alignment diagram of PTA-SEmD-TO was constructed based on the experimental analysis (Fig. S25). Thus, this study highlights the interaction of lattice distortion, defects (Vo), and active sites to optimize the catalytic and optical properties. 3.6 Photothermocatalytic performance To explore the photocatalytic and photothermocatalytic activities, a series of experiments using the as-prepared catalysts were conducted. The photocatalytic activities R CO 2 , i.e., the CO concentration in ppm normalized to the catalyst weight (Fig. 7 a) and CO production (Fig. S26) for 400 ppm CO2/He over the as-prepared catalysts under simulated solar light (1 sun: 100 mW.cm−2) at 30 °C, are displayed. The quasi-disordered catalysts exhibited significant adsorption capacity even for 400 ppm CO2 (Fig. 5). Due to the possible desorption of CO2 under photothermocatalytic conditions (light and heat), CO2 conversion efficiency ( R CO 2 : ppm. g−1. hr−1) was presented in terms of the yield of CO product gas evolved to provide a more accurate representation of the catalytic performance. PTA-SEmD-TO, characterized by an interface between a disordered Sn (IV, II) surface and PTA (W6+), favorable optical features, low charge recombination (section 2.5), and high-density surface sFLPs, showed an efficient photocatalytic CO2 activity ( R CO 2 ) of 74 ppm. g−1. hr−1 and CO production of 0.64 μmol. g−1. hr−1. In contrast, pristine SnO2 and SEmD-TO (350) exhibited no quantifiable activity, owing to their unfavorable potential for CO2 reduction. The photothermocatalytic CO2 activities of the as-prepared catalysts were studied at 120 °C (Fig. 7b). The optimized PTA- SEmD-TO displayed a 576 % increase in R CO 2 (507 ppm. g−1. hr−1) compared to the activity at 30 °C, benefiting from the combined synergy of light and heat. Accordingly, PTA-SEmD-TO displayed the highest CO production rate of 3.98 μmol. g−1. hr−1 (Fig. S27). The CO2 conversion activity was enhanced at higher temperatures because of increased CO2 activation and the faster transfer of photogenerated electrons from the catalyst surface to the interacting CO2. Pristine SnO2 and SEmD-TO (350) exhibited nominal activities compared to those of PTA-SEmD-TO, SEmD-TO (AS), and SEmD-TO (120) (Fig. 7b and Fig. S27). The pristine SnO2 and SEmD-TO (350) activities at elevated temperatures could be related to the expanded energy distribution at high temperatures, which enabled a fraction of the electrons to overcome the energy barrier [57,58]. Nevertheless, it is noteworthy that heat can enhance the energy level and reactivity of photogenerated electrons, and PTA-SEmD-TO, SEmD-TO (AS), and SEmD-TO (120) with suitable active sites provided more efficient CO2 photothermocatalytic activities. The relationship between the photothermocatalytic activity and the concentrations of OL (Sn − O) and OH (Sn − OH) species is shown in Fig. 7c. A volcano-shaped activity trend was observed under photothermocatalytic conditions, exhibiting optimal CO2 activity at an approximately 1:1 OL/OH ratio (Table S2). However, the catalytic activity decreased when the ratio deviated from the optimal value (1:1). Furthermore, a comparison between 400 ppm CO2/air and 400 ppm CO2/He revealed slightly better activity under air conditions (Fig. 7d and Fig. S28). The underlying reason for the improved activity in the air could be the presence of surface-adsorbed O2 – species, providing additional Lewis base sites for CO2 surface attachment. In addition, surface-activated O2 can stabilize the Sn (IV, II) state and the OL/OH ratio by repopulating the photogenerated Vo. The following reaction mechanism provides a detailed discussion of this phenomenon (Section 3.7). To further explore the catalytic properties of PTA-SEmD-TO, temperature-dependent experiments were performed at constant sunlight intensity (100 mW.cm−2) for 400 ppm CO2/air to evidence the coupling effect of light and heat in solar-driven catalysis [58]. The CO2 photocatalytic activity (Fig. 7e) and the corresponding CO production (Fig. S29) showed an almost linear increase as the temperature increased from 30 to 150 °C. Additionally, an Arrhenius plot was presented to evaluate the reaction activity by analyzing the relationship between activity and temperature for SnO2 and PTA-SEmD-TO (Fig. 7f). For SnO2, no measurable CO production was observed at 30 °C, but the CO production was increased with increasing temperature. This nonlinear variance of SnO2 resulted from the apparent low reaction rate at low temperatures. However, PTA-SEmD-TO showed a higher reaction rate as a result of photoactivation. The observed linear relationship in the Arrhenius plot indicated that the reaction followed temperature-dependent kinetics, as expected from the chemical kinetics [11]. The linear increase in activity confirmed that the enhancement in CO2 activity was derived from the combined solar light and temperature effects. Furthermore, as the light intensity was halved from 100 mW.cm−2 to 50 mW.cm−2, the linear decrease in CO production (Fig. S30a) and photothermocatalytic activity (Fig. S30b) confirmed that the enhanced activity of CO2 reduction upon light irradiation followed a photothermocatalytic reaction. A performance comparison between 400 ppm CO2/air and 100 % CO2 (Fig. S31) showed greater CO production at higher CO2 concentrations. Even under simulated solar light, the excellent performance was attributed to sFLPs, disorder engineering, and interfacial junctions (Table S5). This study presents valuable insights into harnessing ambient higher temperatures in diverse regions globally (decentralization) and utilizing waste heat energy in industrial settings (point source). By combining solar light with industrial waste heat energy or ambient temperatures in hotter regions, the efficiency of CO2 reduction can be significantly enhanced. In the CO2 isotope-labeled experiments to confirm the carbon source, the CO products of 12CO2 and 13CO2 were analyzed by gas chromatography (GC) based on their different retention times (Fig. S32a and b). Furthermore, the products of the 13CO2 reaction were analyzed using GC–MS (Fig. S32c – e). GC–MS analysis confirmed that the m/z values corresponded to 13CO (m/z = 29), 13CO2 (m/z = 45), and H2O (m/z = 18). The combined results of GC retention time and GC–MS analysis showed that the photothermocatalytic products originated from CO2 reduction. Control experiments also confirmed negligible CO formation in the case without the catalyst and only slight activity in dark conditions at 120 ℃ compared to the photothermocatalytic conditions (Fig. S33). This also confirmed the light-enhanced effect on the catalytic activity due to the combined effect of light and heat [59,60]. The stability of PTA-SEmD-TO (Fig. S34a) was evaluated under photothermocatalytic conditions for five cycles. In each run, after the catalyst was illuminated for 4 h, the reactor was evacuated and refilled with CO2 before the start of the next cycle. It was observed that the CO production rate dropped after the 2nd cycle, and the subsequent 4th cycle approached reaction stability, showing only a slight decrease in performance. The observed decline in the catalyst performance over an extended period might be attributed to Sn-OH loss. This work showed that the enhanced catalytic activity correlated with the disorder engineering and formation of sFLPs. The disordered catalysts exhibited abundant defects and formation of Sn − OH compared to pristine SnO2. The optimum ratio of Sn − OH to Sn − OL exerted considerable influence on photothermocatalytic activity by promoting CO2 adsorption and activation (Fig. 7c). To confirm it, the catalyst was subjected to hydrolysis after the 4th cycle. The used catalyst was suspended in the DI water and kept on stirring for 8 hr. After the hydrolysis, the catalyst activity during an initial reaction period recovered to that of the fresh catalyst. However, as the reaction proceeded, the catalyst activity declined again. XPS analysis (Table S6: after 1st and 5th cycle) and FTIR analysis (Fig. S34b: after 5th cycle) revealed a noticeable reduction in OH content, providing clear evidence for the correlation between Sn − OH and CO2 conversion efficiency [14,61]. Furthermore, the corresponding vibrational peaks ascribed to PTA at 870 and 943 cm−1 (Fig. S34b) showed no significant change compared to the fresh catalyst. The peaks in FTIR spectra for the used catalyst at 2851 and 2918 cm−1 were ascribed to COOH*, a key intermediate for CO2 to CO [62]. The C 1 s spectra of fresh and after the 5th cyclic test for PTA-SEmD-TO are exhibited in Fig. S35a. The fresh spectra showed adventitious carbon (284.8 eV) and bicarbonate (288.57 eV) due to CO2 activation on sFLPs. After the 5th cyclic test, new components appeared in the C 1 s spectra at 286.44 and 292.3 eV, corresponding to *COOH and CO2 – species, respectively [63]. The C 1 s spectra after the cyclic tests also confirmed the presence of surface intermediate species on the surface. 3.7 Possible reaction mechanism and O2 contribution The reaction mechanism of the enhanced CO2 photothermocatalytic activity can be proposed by combining the experimental and analytical results (Fig. 8 ). Ultradilute CO2 was activated into the m-CO3 2−, b-CO3 2−, HCO3 –, and CO2– species by sFLPs, Sn (II) electrons, and in-plane Vo (Fig. 5e and f). Furthermore, O2 was chemisorbed as O2 – at the remaining uncovered Vo sites. The interaction of carbon atoms (CO2) with the catalyst surface decreased the charge density around the lattice oxygen adjacent to Vo (Fig. 5e and f). Therefore, the rapidly forming photogenerated holes oxidize the low-charge-density lattice oxygen to establish Vo. Consequently, Sn (IV) was reduced to Sn (II) to maintain the overall charge configuration within the lattice (Step 2, Fig. 8). However, O2 diffusion and H2O oxidation at the in-plane Vo sites can repopulate the photogenerated Vo. The interaction of water vapor with freshly produced Vo can release two H+ ions and oxygen to fill some of the Vo (Step 3, Fig. 8) [5]. The freshly produced electrons and H+ converted CO2 into CO* via a reduction reaction (Step 4, Fig. 8). Subsequently, CO* was released from the surface as CO (Step 5, Fig. 8) [46]. Importantly, the presence of CO3 2– and O2 – species on the catalyst surface and Vo sites can significantly hinder the re-adsorption of CO [64,65]. Meanwhile, O2 in CO2/air can repopulate the remaining photogenerated Vo to restore the original state of the catalyst (Step 6, Fig. 8). As presented in the photothermocatalytic activity experiments (Fig. 7c), optimum disorder is essential to maximize photothermocatalytic activity. However, the photogenerated Vo and a higher degree of disorder can cause activity loss. Post-photothermocatalytic XPS analysis of used catalysts revealed that pristine SnO2 underwent significant metal reduction owing to the photogenerated Vo and structural modifications (Figs. S35 and S36). The binding energy shift in O1s spectra for PTA-SEmD-TO (Fig. S35b) under CO2 photothermocatalytic conditions could be attributed to dynamic changes in the chemical environment. Initially, as the catalyst engaged in CO2 photoreduction, the binding energy increased due to the interaction of oxygen with catalyst surface species (Fig. 6). Subsequently, as the reaction progressed the binding energy decreased due to a change in chemical state. However, for SnO2 (Fig. S35c) the O 1 s spectra exhibited a decrease in the binding energy even after 1st cycle due to the reduction of metal state [66]. This was also evident from the color change of SnO2 to dark gray (Fig. S36b inset). In contrast, PTA-SEmD-TO maintained its mixed metal state (Fig. S36, Table S6) and retained its original color (Fig. S36d inset). Additionally, the O2 interaction was also observed via the EPR analysis over PTA-SEmD-TO (Fig. 6). It further supported the involvement of O2 in repopulating the photogenerated Vo. These findings confirmed the dynamic role of O2 in stabilizing the metal states by replenishing the photogenerated Vo in PTA-SEmD-TO (Fig. 6). A comparison of the W 4f binding energies before and after the reaction (1st and 5th cycle) revealed negative shift in binding energies (Fig. S37). The shift indicated an increased charge density around W6+ as a result of photogenerated electron transfer at the Sn-W interface [67]. Furthermore, no other significant changes were observed, confirming the FTIR results in Fig. S34b. The electrons around W6+ could be further transferred to surface-adsorbed CO2 to promote conversion. Therefore, the sFLPs induced by Sn-W and OH facilitated CO2 activation and electron transfer for enhanced photothermocatalytic conversion. The EPR analysis of PTA-SEmD-TO after the reaction revealed an increased spectral intensity at a g-value of 4.3 (Fig. S38), suggesting the participation of photogenerated electrons and holes in the formation of oxygen hole centers. Additionally, a shoulder peak at a g-value of 2.003 suggested the prevention of electron-hole recombination, consistent with the PL spectra (Fig. S23) [68]. This study highlighted the significant impact of high-density sFLPs on optimized disordered Sn catalysts in promoting the photothermocatalytic conversion of CO2 from air. 4 Conclusion In summary, a high-density sFLPs catalyst was developed for the bifunctional capture and solar photothermocatalytic conversion of dilute CO2 from air. The optimized catalyst exhibited enhanced adsorption and photothermocatalytic activity. The observed synergy was derived from several features, such as the contribution of high-density sFLPs to CO2 activation and electron migration for CO2 reduction, optimized disorder extent, delocalized valence band, favorable optical properties, reduced charge recombination rate, and improved charge mobility. Moreover, the improved surface chemistry for facilitating O2 chemisorption led to further enhancement of CO2 adsorption and activation by providing intermediate sFLPs sites. The optimized PTA-SEmD-TO catalyst exhibited efficient photothermocatalytic activity, achieving 1499 ppm. g−1.h−1 of R CO 2 activity and 9.38 µmol. g−1.h−1 of CO production at 150 °C for 400 ppm CO2 in wet air. The integration of high-density sFLPs on a disorder-engineered Sn-based heterostructures presents a promising avenue for implementing photothermocatalytic CO2 reduction at low concentrations using H2O, thereby providing a roadmap for catalyst design to achieve ambitious carbon neutrality goals. coredata.dc:description: Designing adsorption-enhanced solid catalysts with excellent bifunctional features is feasible for achieving carbon neutrality. In this study, surface-frustrated Lewis pair sites (sFLPs) were fabricated on a quasi-disordered Sn catalyst. Catalysts with different degrees of disorder were synthesized by thermochemical control. The disordered catalyst exhibited randomly distributed lattice disorder, in-plane oxygen vacancies, and mixed-valence Sn. The coexistence of Sn (IV, II) Lewis acidic sites and −OH Lewis basic sites was crucial in the activation of CO2. In addition, sFLPs were further stimulated on the disorder-engineered surface using simultaneous inclusion of PTA (W6+) and hydroxylation. The optimized catalyst exhibited an exceptionally high adsorption capacity and photothermocatalytic activity for 400 ppm CO2 in air compared to pristine SnO2. The enhanced adsorption and photothermocatalytic activity were attributed to distinctive chemistry of the redox-active sFLPs. This study highlights the potential of high-density sFLPs on disordered catalysts for CO2 abatement from the air.
coredata.dc:title: Invigorating surface frustrated Lewis pairs on bifunctional quasi-disordered Sn-based catalyst for solar photothermocatalytic conversion of CO2 from air
